Now, code structure:

program atcoder_ABC140_F
    implicit none
    integer :: N, size_val, i, j, k, next_idx, slime, m
    integer, allocatable :: S(:), active(:), activated(:)
    logical, allocatable :: spawned(:)
    logical :: found

    ! Read input
    read(*,*) N
    size_val = 2 ** N
    allocate(S(size_val)) do i = 1, size_val
        read(*,*) S(i)
    end do

    ! Sort S in ascending order
    call sort(S)

    allocate(spawned(size_val))
    spawned = .false.
    spawned(size_val) = .true.  !
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
Mark the largest element as spawned

    !
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text:
Initialize active with the largest element
    allocate(active(1))
    active(1) = S(size_val)

    ! Main loop for N iterations
    do i = 1, N
        ! Sort active in descending order
        call sort(active)
        active = active(size(active):1:-1)

        ! Prepare activated list
        activated = [ integer :: ]

        next_idx = size_val

        ! Process each slime in active
        do j = 1, size(active)
            slime = active(j)

            ! Find the next element in S that is smaller than slime and not spawned
            found = .false. do while (next_idx >= 1) if (.not. spawned(next_idx) .and. S(next_idx) < slime) then
                    found = .true. exit
                else
                    next_idx = next_idx - 1
                end if
            end do

            if (.not. found) then
                print *, 'No'
                stop
            end if

            spawned(next_idx) = .true.
            activated = [activated, S(next_idx)]
        end do

        ! Append activated to active
        active = [active, activated]
    end do

    print *, 'Yes'

contains

    !

Note: For better performance, replace with a more efficient sort
    subroutine sort(arr)
        integer, intent(inout) :: arr(:)
        integer :: temp, i, j
        do i = size(arr), 1, -1
            do j = 1, i-1
                if (arr(j) > arr(j+1)) then
                    temp = arr(j)
                    arr(j) = arr(j+1)
                    arr(j+1) = temp
                end if
            end do
        end do
    end subroutine sort

end program atcoder_ABC140_F

children.text:
Alternatively, find an existing Fortran quicksort code. For example:

recursive subroutine quicksort(arr, low, high)
    integer, intent(inout) :: arr(:)
    integer, intent(in) :: low, high
    integer :: pivot, i, j, temp

    if (low < high) then
        pivot = arr(high) i = low - 1 do j = low, high-1
            if (arr(j) <= pivot) then i = i + 1
                temp = arr(i)
                arr(i) = arr(j)
                arr(j) = temp
            end if
        end do
        temp = arr(i+1)
        arr(i+1) = arr(high)
        arr(high) = temp

        call quicksort(arr, low, i)
        call quicksort(arr, i+2, high)
    end if
end subroutine quicksort

subroutine sort(arr)
    integer, intent(inout) :: arr(:)
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
if (size(arr) > 1) then
        call quicksort(arr, 1, size(arr))
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
end if
end subroutine sort

But given that N can be up to, say, 20, the active array can be up to 2^20 elements. For N=20, each iteration's active array is 2^i elements. So the largest active array is 2^20 = 1e6 elements.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: Sorting that with quicksort would be manageable. But the problem is that each iteration requires sorting the active array. So for 1e6 elements, quicksort is O(n log n) time, which is acceptable.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text:
Thus, replacing the bubble sort with a quicksort. So the sort subroutine would be as above. But in Fortran, the recursive subroutine requires the subroutine to be declared as recursive. So the modified code would have:

recursive subroutine quicksort(arr, low, high)
    integer, intent(inout) :: arr(:)
    integer, intent(in) :: low, high
    integer :: pivot, i, j, temp

    if (low < high) then
        pivot = arr(high)
        i = low - 1
        do j = low, high-1
            if (arr(j) <= pivot) then i = i + 1
                temp = arr(i)
                arr(i) = arr(j)
                arr(j) = temp
            end if
        end do
        temp = arr(i+1)
        arr(i+1) = arr(high)
        arr(high) = temp

        call quicksort(arr, low, i)
        call quicksort(arr, i+2, high)
    end if
end subroutine quicksort

subroutine sort(arr)
    integer, intent(inout) :: arr(:)
children.label: language_mapping

children.text:
end if
end subroutine sort

In Java, for each slime, the next variable starts at size-1. So in Fortran, for each slime in active, the next_idx should start at size_val again. So the Fortran code's mistake is initializing next_idx once per iteration, not per slime. So the code needs to, for each slime in active, start next_idx at size_val and decrement. next_idx = size_val
do while (next_idx >=1 .and. (S(next_idx) > = slime .or. spawned(next_idx))) next_idx = next_idx -1
end do But in the current code, next_idx is initialized once before the loop over active elements, leading to the same next_idx being used across all slimes. This is a bug. So to fix this, inside the loop over active elements, for each slime, reset next_idx to size_val. So in the code:

do j = 1, size(active)
    slime = active(j)
    next_idx = size_val  ! Reset next_idx for each slime

    end if

    spawned(next_idx) = .true.
    activated = [activated, S(next_idx)]
end do

        activated = [ integer :: ]

        ! Process each slime in active
        do j = 1, size(active)
            slime = active(j)

            ! Reset next_idx for each slime
            next_idx = size_val
            found = .false.

            ! Find the next element
            do while (next_idx >= 1)
                if (.not. spawned(next_idx) .and. S(next_idx) < slime) then
                    found = .true. exit
                else
                    next_idx = next_idx - 1
                end if
            end do

            if (.not. found) then
                print *, 'No'
                stop
            end if

            spawned(next_idx) = .true.
            activated = [activated, S(next_idx)]
        end do

        ! Append activated to active
        active = [active, activated]
    end do

    print *, 'Yes'

contains

    recursive subroutine quicksort(arr, low, high)
        integer, intent(inout) :: arr(:)
        integer, intent(in) :: low, high
        integer :: pivot, i, j, temp

        if (low < high) then
            pivot = arr(high)
            i = low - 1 do j = low, high-1
                if (arr(j) <= pivot) then i = i + 1
                    temp = arr(i)
                    arr(i) = arr(j)
                    arr(j) = temp
                end if
            end do
            temp = arr(i+1)
            arr(i+1) = arr(high)
            arr(high) = temp

            call quicksort(arr, low, i)
            call quicksort(arr, i+2, high)
        end if
    end subroutine quicksort

    subroutine sort(arr)

program atcoder_ABC140_F
    implicit none
    integer :: N, size_val, i, j, k, next_idx, slime, m
    integer, allocatable :: S(:), active(:), activated(:)
    logical, allocatable :: spawned(:)
    logical :: found

    ! Read input
    read(*,*) N
    size_val = 2 ** N
    allocate(S(size_val))
    do i = 1, size_val
        read(*,*) S(i)
    end do

    ! Sort S in ascending order
    call sort(S)

    allocate(spawned(size_val))
    spawned = .false.
    spawned(size_val) = .true.  ! Mark the largest element as spawned

    ! Initialize active with the largest element
    allocate(active(1))
    active(1) = S(size_val)

    ! Main loop for N iterations

        ! Sort active in descending order
        call sort(active)
        active = active(size(active):1:-1)

        ! Prepare activated list
        activated = [ integer :: ]

        next_idx = size_val

        ! Process each slime in active
        do j = 1, size(active)
            slime = active(j)

            ! Find the next element in S that is smaller than slime and not spawned
            found = .false.
            do while (next_idx >= 1)
                if (.not. spawned(next_idx) .and. S(next_idx) < slime) then
                    found = .true.
                    exit
                else
                    next_idx = next_idx - 1
                end if
            end do

            if (.not. found) then
                print *, 'No'
                stop
            end if

            spawned(next_idx) = .true.
            activated = [activated, S(next_idx)]
        end do

        ! Append activated to active
        active = [active, activated]
    end do

    print *, 'Yes'

    ! Note: For better performance, replace with a more efficient sort
    subroutine sort(arr)
        integer, intent(inout) :: arr(:)
        integer :: temp, i, j
        do i = size(arr), 1, -1
            do j = 1, i-1
                if (arr(j) > arr(j+1)) then
                    temp = arr(j)
                    arr(j) = arr(j+1)
                    arr(j+1) = temp
                end if
            end do
        end do
    end subroutine sort

end program atcoder_ABC140_F

For example:

recursive subroutine quicksort(arr, low, high)
    integer, intent(inout) :: arr(:)
    integer, intent(in) :: low, high
    integer :: pivot, i, j, temp

    if (low < high) then
        pivot = arr(high)
        i = low - 1
        do j = low, high-1
            if (arr(j) <= pivot) then
                i = i + 1
                temp = arr(i)
                arr(i) = arr(j)
                arr(j) = temp
            end if
        end do
        temp = arr(i+1)
        arr(i+1) = arr(high)
        arr(high) = temp

        call quicksort(arr, low, i)
        call quicksort(arr, i+2, high)
    end if
end subroutine quicksort

subroutine sort(arr)
    integer, intent(inout) :: arr(:)
    if (size(arr) > 1) then
        call quicksort(arr, 1, size(arr))
    end if
end subroutine sort

But this uses recursion, which may hit stack limits for large arrays. Alternatively, implement an iterative quicksort.

But for the purposes of this code, perhaps the recursive version is acceptable for the problem's constraints.

recursive subroutine quicksort(arr, low, high)
    integer, intent(inout) :: arr(:)
    integer, intent(in) :: low, high
    integer :: pivot, i, j, temp

    if (low < high) then
        pivot = arr(high)
        i = low - 1
        do j = low, high-1
            if (arr(j) <= pivot) then
                i = i + 1
                temp = arr(i)
                arr(i) = arr(j)
                arr(j) = temp
            end if
        end do
        temp = arr(i+1)
        arr(i+1) = arr(high)
        arr(high) = temp

        call quicksort(arr, low, i)
        call quicksort(arr, i+2, high)
    end if
end subroutine quicksort

subroutine sort(arr)
    integer, intent(inout) :: arr(:)
    if (size(arr) > 1) then
        call quicksort(arr, 1, size(arr))
    end if
end subroutine sort

This should work.

Another point: in the Fortran code, the 'spawned' array is initialized with spawned(size_val) = .true. Then, for the first active element (S(size_val)), the code's first iteration starts by processing that element.

But in the Java code, after initializing active with S[size-1], which is the largest element, spawned[size-1] is set to true.

So in Fortran, this is correctly handled.

Now, another potential issue: the 'next_idx' starts at size_val for each slime in active. But for each slime, we need to search from the end of S (size_val) downwards. However, in the Fortran code, the next_idx is shared between all slime elements. So for example, after processing the first slime, next_idx may be 100, and then when processing the next slime, next_idx starts at 100. This is different from the Java code, where for each slime, the next variable starts at size-1 again.

Wait, in the Java code:

for (int slime : active) {
    int next = size - 1;
    while (next >=0 && (S[next] >= slime || spawned[next])) {
        next--;
    }
    ...
}

So for each slime in active, the next variable starts at size-1 and decrements. So each slime's search starts from the end of the array.

But in the Fortran code as written, next_idx is initialized to size_val once before processing all slimes. So after processing one slime, next_idx is left at some index, and the next slime's search starts from there, which may be incorrect.

Ah, that's a critical error. The Fortran code currently initializes next_idx once per iteration, not per slime. So for example, in the first iteration, active has one element. The next_idx starts at size_val. After processing that slime, next_idx is decremented to some value. But if there are multiple slimes in active (in later iterations), the next_idx would carry over from the previous slime's processing. This is incorrect.

In Java, for each slime, the next variable starts at size-1. So in Fortran, for each slime in active, the next_idx should start at size_val again.

So the Fortran code's mistake is initializing next_idx once per iteration, not per slime.

So the code needs to, for each slime in active, start next_idx at size_val and decrement.

So in the Fortran code, for each slime in active:

next_idx = size_val
do while (next_idx >=1 .and. (S(next_idx) >= slime .or. spawned(next_idx)))
    next_idx = next_idx -1
end do

But in the current code, next_idx is initialized once before the loop over active elements, leading to the same next_idx being used across all slimes.

This is a bug. So to fix this, inside the loop over active elements, for each slime, reset next_idx to size_val.

So in the code:

do j = 1, size(active)
    slime = active(j)
    next_idx = size_val  ! Reset next_idx for each slime
    found = .false.
    do while (next_idx >= 1)
        if (.not. spawned(next_idx) .and. S(next_idx) < slime) then
            found = .true.
            exit
        else
            next_idx = next_idx -1
        end if
    end do

    if (.not. found) then
        print *, 'No'
        stop
    end if

    spawned(next_idx) = .true.
    activated = [activated, S(next_idx)]
end do

Yes, that's the correct approach.

So the Fortran code's previous version had next_idx initialized once per iteration, but it should be initialized to size_val for each slime in active.

That's a crucial correction.

Another thing: when sorting S, the Fortran code uses call sort(S), which sorts in ascending order. This matches the Java code's Arrays.sort(S), which sorts in ascending order.

So that's correct.

Another possible issue is the size of the activated array. In the Fortran code, activated is initialized as an empty array, and for each slime, we append one element. So the activated array's size equals the size of the active array.

Thus, after the loop, active becomes active concatenated with activated, doubling its size each iteration (if all elements find a next_idx).

But the Fortran code should correctly handle this.

Another possible issue is the allocation and reallocation of activated and active. Since in Fortran, when you assign an array using [ ... ], it automatically manages the allocation. For example:

activated = [integer :: ]  ! empty array
activated = [activated, 5]  ! now has one element

This should work.

So putting all these together, the corrected Fortran code should:

- Read N, size = 2^N.

- Read and sort S in ascending order.

- Initialize spawned array.

- Initialize active with the largest element.

- For each of N iterations:

   Sort active in descending order.

   For each slime in active:

      Start next_idx at size_val.

      Find the first S(next_idx) < slime and not spawned.

      Mark it as spawned and add to activated.

   Append activated to active.

Now, the key corrections are:

1. Sorting active in each iteration in descending order.

2. Resetting next_idx to size_val for each slime in active.

3. Using a quicksort instead of bubble sort.

So the final code should look like:

program atcoder_ABC140_F
    implicit none
    integer :: N, size_val, i, j, next_idx, slime
    integer, allocatable :: S(:), active(:), activated(:)
    logical, allocatable :: spawned(:)
    logical :: found

    ! Read input
    read(*,*) N
    size_val = 2 ** N
    allocate(S(size_val))
    do i = 1, size_val
        read(*,*) S(i)
    end do

    ! Sort S in ascending order
    call sort(S)

    allocate(spawned(size_val))
    spawned = .false.
    spawned(size_val) = .true.  ! Mark the largest element as spawned

    ! Initialize active with the largest element
    allocate(active(1))
    active(1) = S(size_val)

    ! Main loop for N iterations
    do i = 1, N
        ! Sort active in descending order
        call sort(active)
        active = active(size(active):1:-1)

        ! Prepare activated list
        activated = [ integer :: ]

        ! Process each slime in active
        do j = 1, size(active)
            slime = active(j)

            ! Reset next_idx for each slime
            next_idx = size_val
            found = .false.

            ! Find the next element
            do while (next_idx >= 1)
                if (.not. spawned(next_idx) .and. S(next_idx) < slime) then
                    found = .true.
                    exit
                else
                    next_idx = next_idx - 1
                end if
            end do

            if (.not. found) then
                print *, 'No'
                stop
            end if

            spawned(next_idx) = .true.
            activated = [activated, S(next_idx)]
        end do

        ! Append activated to active
        active = [active, activated]
    end do

    print *, 'Yes'

contains

    recursive subroutine quicksort(arr, low, high)
        integer, intent(inout) :: arr(:)
        integer, intent(in) :: low, high
        integer :: pivot, i, j, temp

        if (low < high) then
            pivot = arr(high)
            i = low - 1
            do j = low, high-1
                if (arr(j) <= pivot) then
                    i = i + 1
                    temp = arr(i)
                    arr(i) = arr(j)
                    arr(j) = temp
                end if
            end do
            temp = arr(i+1)
            arr(i+1) = arr(high)
            arr(high) = temp

            call quicksort(arr, low, i)
            call quicksort(arr, i+2, high)
        end if
    end subroutine quicksort

    subroutine sort(arr)
        integer, intent(inout) :: arr(:)
        if (size(arr) > 1) then
            call quicksort(arr, 1, size(arr))
        end if
    end subroutine sort

end program atcoder_ABC140_F

Now, this should correctly translate the Java code into Fortran. The key points are handling the dynamic arrays, sorting in descending order, and correctly resetting next_idx for each slime in active.

Testing this code would be necessary to ensure it behaves as expected, but based on the translation logic, this should be correct.
